originalMessage:
While not specifically Meridian, I love that West Ada schools are exploring options for armed security guards.  I'm a high-level firearms instructor with some specialized knowledge in this area.  Leaving the handling of an active threat up to the 911 system and waiting through the entire response sequence pretty much guarantees a huge win (i.e., international notoriety) for the attacker and an unforgettable tragedy for our community.  Get capable, armed people (I would add certain concealed carriers, too) in there on every hallway, on every playground, and in every common area!  And I say that as a parent of a 7th-grader in the WA school district.

After that, we must NEVER emulate Minneapolis!  If we don't like a law, people in a constitutional republic must communicate with their elected representatives about changing the law.  Impeding law enforcement, urban occupations that destroy businesses, rioting, looting, burning, and ANY physical violence MUST be met with the full power of law enforcement--including a prosecuting attorney and judges who will make examples of the rioters.

On a lighter note, can something be done about the sprawling goat-head thorn vines on some of our sidewalks?  (Locust Grove, just north of Franklin, for example.)  That's bad news for kids on bikes and even a real nuisance in shoes and car tires.
atomicMessage: Local schools should explore options for armed security guards and capable armed personnel in hallways and common areas to prevent tragedies.
summary: Constituents disagree on whether to deploy armed personnel within local schools to prevent violence.

originalMessage:
The massive construction increase in our district of multifamily homes. The impact to roads, schools, and public services. 
In the last 2 years we've seen such an impact. And the huge project at Ten Mile to Black Cat. Why does Meridian need another Village.
And the industrial buildings that have been built and sit empty. Why are we destroying our beautiful farmlands for empty, ugly buildings. Our neighborhoods have changed so drastically they are not recognizable from 5 years ago.
atomicMessage: The massive increase in construction of multifamily homes in the local area.
summary: Residents demand a halt to high-density construction to protect community character and prevent strain on public infrastructure.
